data.value: is supported for DataFrame/Series with a MultiIndex.

The 'krogh', 'piecewise_polynomial', 'spline', 'pchip' and 'akima' methods are wrappers around the respective SciPy implementations of similar names. These use the actual numerical values of the index. For more information on their behavior, see the
Interpolation technique to use. One of:
'linear': Ignore the index and treat the values as equally   spaced. This is the only method supported on MultiIndexes.
'time': Works on daily and higher resolution data to interpolate   given length of interval.
'index', 'values': use the actual numerical values of the index.
'pad': Fill in NaNs using existing values.
. These methods use the numerical   values of the index.  Both 'polynomial' and 'spline' require that   you also specify an
'krogh', 'piecewise_polynomial', 'spline', 'pchip', 'akima',   'cubicspline': Wrappers around the SciPy interpolation methods of   similar names. See
which   replaces 'piecewise_polynomial' interpolation method in   scipy 0.18.
Maximum number of consecutive NaNs to fill. Must be greater than 0.
Update the data in place if possible.
Consecutive NaNs will be filled in this direction.
If 'method' is 'backfill' or 'bfill', the default is 'backward'

raises ValueError if `limit_direction` is ' forward ' or ' both ' and method is ' backfill ' or ' bfill ' . raises ValueError if `limit_direction` is ' backward ' or ' both ' and method is ' pad ' or ' ffill ' .
If limit is specified, consecutive NaNs will be filled with this restriction.
'inside': Only fill NaNs surrounded by valid values   (interpolate).
'outside': Only fill NaNs outside valid values (extrapolate).

data.type_: optional, 'infer' or None, defaults to None

data.value: Keyword arguments to pass on to the interpolating function.
Returns the same object type as the caller, interpolated at some or all
Fill NaN values using an interpolation method.

data.value: in a Series via polynomial interpolation or splines: Both 'polynomial' and 'spline' methods require that you also specify an
Fill the DataFrame forward (that is, going down) along each column using linear interpolation.
Note how the last entry in column 'a' is interpolated differently, because there is no entry after it to use for interpolation. Note how the first entry in column 'b' remains
, because there is no entry before it to use for interpolation.
Fill missing values using different methods.
Piecewise polynomial in the Bernstein basis.

signature.value: interpolate(self: 'NDFrameT', method: 'str' = 'linear', axis: 'Axis' = 0, limit: 'int | None' = None, inplace: 'bool_t' = False, limit_direction: 'str | None' = None, limit_area: 'str | None' = None, downcast: 'str | None' = None, **kwargs) -> 'NDFrameT | None'
